III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
Description contact with children or parents to be a person who has the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation Agency staff member brought a youth to the hospital and reported
that youth continuously sexually assaulted the staff member
throughout the past week. This was reported to the employee's
supervisor and no known action was taken.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant:
On 8/28/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone.
Complainant reported on 8/21/2024, Foster Care Worker (FCW) 1
brought Youth A to the hospital’s mental health unit for evaluation
and FCW 1 was sent to the hospital’s Emergency Unit, as that
was more appropriate given Youth A’s situation at the time.
Complainant reported concern related to her interaction with FCW
1, birth mother, Youth A and a supervisor who had arrived with the
birth mother during the hospital’s interaction with FCW 1 and
Youth A. Complainant said all parties were escalated, and she
talked to birth mother. She also observed bruises on Youth A’s
neck which were reported as being caused by another youth, in
the foster home, whom Youth A had attacked. She reported while
she was speaking with FCW to explain the hospital would not do
an inpatient admission of him at that time, FCW 1 began to cry
and stated Youth A has sexually assaulted her repeatedly over the
last week. FCW 1 stated Youth A has also sexually assaulting his
foster parent. FCW 1 did not give details as to what that assault
entailed or where the youth may have touched her or the foster
parent. FCW 1 reported “they assign him to me every day”.
Complainant said she questioned whether FCW 1 felt safe. She
asked FCW 1 whether she had reported this matter to her
supervisor and asked who that person was. FCW 1 responded
she had reported the matter, and that she was told “We all have
clients like this” that she has to deal with it. FCW 1 reported she
2

had not reported this matter to the police, but she would do so
today. FCW 1 reported Youth A would return to his respite home
for later psychiatric follow up.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 1
On 9/9/2024 I interviewed FCW 1 by telephone. FCW 1 reported
she is new to child welfare and has only worked as a case worker
at the agency for four months. She reported being assigned to
Youth A’s case on 7/24/2024. It was transferred from the agency
Muskegon office and there Youth A’s case was assigned to a
male staff. FCW 1 said ever since she has had Youth A’s case,
Youth A (age 15) has displayed boundary issues. FCW 1
reported, “He won’t stop hugging me, he has asked to hump me;
he has humped my car. He will hang on to me very tight”. She
said he has also made sexual comments like “Do you want this
foot long now or later.” FCW 1 said Youth A did not make that
statement to her, but he has made it to other kids in the foster
home, along with telling one of them that they “have a fat ass”.
She said Youth A has behavioral and psychological issues, and
he likes seeing others react to his bad behavior.
FCW 1 said she was told the agency did not know Youth A had
these sexualized behaviors when they accepted placement of him.
She said she only read about some of the behaviors after she had
held the case. She said the behaviors were not described to the
intensity that he was displaying during his inactions with her and in
the foster homes. She said Youth A’s sexualized behavior with her
has been going on since 7/24/2024. She explained that on
7/29/2024 she had to transport him to his mom for a visit and
though he did okay during the transport, he did not at the visit. He
came up and was touching and swirling her hair, and he would not
stop when asked. If he did stop, he would begin again. This was
the first day he asked to hump her. He also asked to pick her up
after lifting up his mom and he hugged her and would not let go.
FCW 1 admitted that Youth A never tried to touch her private parts
that day or during her time on the case, but that his sexualized
behaviors were escalating and getting worse. She explained a
foster parent asked for his removal after he kept acting out toward
the other children in the home, which on one occasion led to
another child attacking him. She said it was in Youth A’s respite
home where, Youth A had ultimately touched the Respite Foster
Mother’s breast on 8/21/2024 and pulled out a knife and
threatened to break the knife. That was also the day she
transported him to the emergency room for possible psychiatric
admission. She said that day his behavior was the worst, with him
3

running around, touching her hair, holding on to her body and
trying to mess with her car.
FCW 1 reported it being overwhelming handling Youth A’s
behaviors and having to interact with him almost daily for the week
in July 2024 and later in August 2024 when the agency was trying
to get him hospitalized. She said on 7/29/2024, she called
Supervisor due to Youth A’s inappropriate behavior towards her
and her concern/uncomfortableness with Youth A. Supervisor told
her the agency did not know about these behaviors for Youth A,
but FCW 1 reiterated that she later read that the agency not
knowing about the behaviors for Youth A may not have been the
case. She said Supervisor told her to keep her aware of what was
happening on the case and with Youth A. Additionally that, if she
needed someone to go with her when she has to transport Youth
A to ask for assistance. FCW 1 said she did know if she was
perhaps overreacting about her feelings about the youth
behaviors. She said she questioned how could or even should she
ask someone else to assist her, or whether they could
accommodate her, give that her co-workers are also busy and
have full caseloads. FCW reported it was her pride and desire to
success that caused her to push forward with handling Youth A’s
case. She said it was not until they were trying to get Youth A
hospitalized, and she was later informing the police pertaining to
Youth A’s behaviors toward her, that she realized she had been
making excuses for Youth A. That she was never comfortable with
Youth A. She said most times it was hard; and although
sometimes other staff were able to accompany her with Youth A,
most times they could not. She reported wishing the agency had
intervened on her behalf instead of just asking her to keep them
informed of what was going on. In retrospect she wishes the
agency’s management had asked her if the situation was
becoming too much and if she was okay.
FCW 1 did not report asking for Youth A’s case to be transferred
from her caseload. She said she may have been uncomfortable
asking to get this case reassigned, because she was new and she
wanted to keep trying. Also, when FCW 1 was venting about the
case on 8/20/2024 CA 2 said, “you need to get over it, we all have
hard cases.” Due to that statement FCW 1 thought she had no
agency support and no choice but to deal with the situation.
FCW 1 said she continued dealing with Youth A’s behaviors and
his case for three days straight from 8/19/2024 until 8/21/2024,
which was the day before he was placed in a shelter. She told the
agency she would not transport Youth A to his shelter placement
4

on 8/22/2024 and the agency was okay with that. She reported
thereafter DHHS (Department of Health and Human Services)
took Youth A’s case back.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS).
I interviewed FCS by telephone on 9/9/2024. FCS confirmed
information reported by FCW 1 related to, when the agency
received Youth A’s case, from where, behaviors he was
presenting and presenting towards FCW 1, and those behaviors
escalating on 8/19/2024. She also affirmed the reporting about
Youth A acting out against a youth in his former foster home and
being attacked by that youth due to Youth A’s behavior. She
reported after FCW 1 first reported how Youth A behaved with her,
him being touchy feely with her at his/parent youth visitation she
did not want FCW 1 to be alone trying to supervise those
visitations. She reported since Youth A had done well during the
transports to the visitations, she sought to assist FCW 1 along the
lines of the parenting visit site. She asked DHHS to use one of
their visitation rooms where FCW 1 could monitor the visit by way
of one-way mirror. She admitted that visit didn’t work, because
Youth A kept leaving the room, locating FCW 1 and still trying to
hug her or touch her hair. He also left the building and FCW 1 and
his mom had difficulty getting him back inside. FCS reported after
that visit, they sought to put protective protocols in place whereby
a co-worker was to be with FCW 1 to supervise the visit. The,
original plan was for her and FCW 1 to transport Youth A. She
reported that plan did not consistently work out due to scheduling
conflicts for her and FCW 1’s coworkers, but DHHS agreed to
have a worker at the visit to help FCW 1 with supervision of the
parent /youth visit. She said there was no incidents by Youth A at
that next parent/youth visit, but that did not continue for the
following visit. Thereafter the agency continued seeking to get
Youth A mental health assistance.
FCS said FCW 1 did report being uncomfortable with the situation
with Youth A. FCW 1 expressed more concern with Youth A’s
mom. That the mom was not redirecting Youth A’s behaviors. She
said FCW 1 never reported feeling unsafe with Youth A. FCS said
she would advise FCW 1 to redirect Youth A.
FCS affirmed FCW 1’s reporting related to a further incident with
Youth A at Respite Foster Mother’s (RFM) home involving a knife
and Youth A acting out towards RFM on 8/21/2024 when FCW 1
was transporting him from the respite foster home back for his
CMH appointment. FCS reported because of all that was going on
that day she sent FCW 2 to assist FCW 1, to try to help calm and
5

deescalate Youth A. She said that day she was coordinating with
the respite foster parent to file a police report. She also advised
FCW 1 and FCW 2 to file a police report. The agency also safety
planned with the respite foster home afterwards.
FCS reported feeling she did all that she could to help protect
Youth A and to support FCW 1. She said she told FCW 1, she
would find someone else to transport Youth A if FCW 1 didn’t feel
comfortable and FCW 1 reported, ‘No, I will do it.” She said she
also told FCW 1 she would have Youth A’s case transferred, if
FCW 1 didn’t feel comfortable, and FCW 1 reported she could
handle it. She denied ever telling FCW 1 “We all have hard jobs
and to get over it” or being aware of anyone who had made such a
statement to FCW1. FCS denied FCW 1 ever told her someone
had made such a statement like that to her. FCS also denied FCW
1 refusing to transport Youth A on 8/22/2024. FCS said FCW 1
volunteered to do so.
Respite Foster Mother (RFM)
On 9/26/2024 I interviewed RFM by telephone. RFM had no
direct information related to what support the agency provided or
did not provide FCW 1. She was interviewed related to Youth A’s
placement with her, behaviors he presented and what she
witnessed of his interaction with FCW 1. She reported having
Youth A in placement on a temporary basis for two days. She was
told there was an incident in Youth A’s prior foster home. That a
youth got upset with Youth A over something Youth A did. The
youth put hands around Youth A’s neck in retaliation and Youth A
was replaced. She affirmed Youth A having serious behavioral
and psychiatric concerns. She reported FCW 1 coming to her
home to transport Youth A to an appointment in late August 2024,
an incident happening whereby she observed FCW 1’s car horn
going off. FCW 1 was on the phone with a coworker asking for
assistance. FCW 1 said “he just choked me out” and FCW 1 told
her to go back inside and lock the door. She said during that time
Youth A came over and tried to put her in a headlock and FCW 1
came over and got Youth A. RFM said FCW 1’s coworker arrived
about 10 minutes later to assist her with Youth A. She said FCW
1 was calm but shaking while handling the situation with Youth A.
RFM said the only thing FCW 1 reported to her about Youth A
actions with her was that he was a handful, that his aggression
toward her had been verbal in the past not physical. RFM said
she told FCW 1 that Youth A had grabbed a knife and was trying
to get at her. He was licking his lips and tried to get on top of her,
but she got away from him. He was yelling and swearing, and this
6

behavior went on for about 15 minutes before he calmed down
and FCW 1 arrived to transport him. She reported after Youth A
did not get admitted, the agency agreed Youth A would not be
alone with her. They safety planned. She said Youth A tended to
behave this way just with females, that the behaviors he displayed
never came out with her husband.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 2
I interviewed FCW 2 by telephone on 9/27/2024. FCW 2 reported
being employed by the agency less than eight months. She
affirmed information reported by FCW 1 related to Youth A being
difficult due to Youth A sexualized behaviors towards FCW 1.
Additionally, that FCW 1 complained about him. She said she and
FCW 1 shared an office, and FCW 1 complained daily about
Youth A’s verbal and physical harassment of her by calling her a
hoe and slut and him constantly touching her hair or shoulders.
FCW 2 reported hearing FCW 1 calling and telling Supervisor “He
won’t stop touching me, I don’t feel safe with him in my car”. FCW
2 reported FCW 1 reported being scared. FCW 2 reported
Supervisor’s response to FCW 1 was Supervisor telling FCW 1
things like “these things happen, you just have to stop him” that
she has “to tell him to stop, to step away from him”; but his
behaviors never stop. FCW 2 reported Supervisor appeared to
make it seem as if Youth A “was going to perp”, meaning to do
inappropriate touching, no matter what, as opposed to respecting
or protecting FCW 1. FCW 2 said one of their big bosses, Chief
Administrator 2 told FCW 1, “We all have these case, you just
have to smile through it.” She also reported Supervisor sending
her to assist FCW 1 with Youth A at his respite foster home in late
August 2024. FCW 2 said Youth A had only been at this home for
24-hours and he was having an episode. She said Supervisor
was on the phone with FCW 1 and she heard FCW 1 telling Youth
A to get off her, she didn’t want to be touched. Youth A was yelling
at FCW 1. FCW 2 reported when she arrived at the respite home
Youth A was verbally and physically acting out, calling her names,
trying to touch her body. She redirected him. She assisted in
getting him in the car, and they transferred him to his assessment.
FCW 2 affirmed hearing that Youth A did better with males and
indicated the agency had two male staff at the time. One in foster
care and one in independent living. She did not know if a transfer
of Youth A’s case to one of those staff was ever a possibility. She
did not know whether FCW 1 ever asked to be removed from
Youth A’s case or if the agency ever explored it.
Chief Administrator (CA) 2
7

I interviewed CA 2 on 10/23/204 by telephone. I also received an
email statement from her on 9/23/2024. CA 2 denied the agency
not seeking to aid FCW 1 related to handling Youth A’s case,
around him allegedly sexually assaulting her. She denied making
any statement to FCW 1 like she needs to get it over it, that we all
have hard cases, or to being aware of any person making such a
remark of to FCW 1.
CA 2 reported that at the time they accepted Youth A’s case, they
did not know the severity of Youth A’s mental health needs. If they
had they never would have accepted the case. She said at the
time they were serving the case they did not have a male staff to
assign to his case. Nor did they have senior staff, all workers had
similar seniority as FCW 1. She said after learning of Youth A's
behaviors, as reported by FCW 1, Supervisor was working with
FCW 1 around those issues. They also knew that Youth A was
slated to be placed in a residential placement in September 2024
and they were trying to made it to that date. Supervisor was
checking in with FCW 1 regularly and providing assistance
verbally and provided coworker assistance when needed and as
able.
CA 2 said Supervisor also had a conversation with FCW 1 about
transferring the case to another worker and FCW 1 wanted to stay
on the case. FCW 1 said she could handle it. CA 2 said they also
tried to give Youth A’s case to DHHS before his ultimate late
August 2024 case termination from the agency and DHHS would
not take the case back at that time. When Youth A went into a
shelter on 8/22/2024 or 8/23/2024 DHHS agreed to take the case
back.
Documents Reviewed
Youth A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• He entered care in 2019 and is a temporary court ward.
• He was placed with Holy Cross Muskegon on 6/24/2024
then placed with this Holy Cross office on 7/24/2024.
• He was placed in RFM’s foster home on 8/20/2024 until
8/22/2024.
• His diagnoses include disruptive mood deregulation
disorder, oppositional deficit disorder, attention deficit-
hyperactivity disorder/ predominant hyperactive/impulsive
presentation.
• A copy of social work contacts from FCS showing
information about Youth A’s behavior in his prior foster
home on 8/16/2024, as reported about that incident, and
8

onward to 8/21/2024 when Youth A was taken to the
hospital and FCS went there to assist FCW 1.
Analysis Based on interviews and case information reviewed it is clear
Youth A had mental health issues impacting his acting out
behaviors. The evidence also showed some assistance was
offered FCW 1, in dealing with Youth A, on handling this difficult
case, but the degree of that assistance or its effectiveness, as well
as, whether FCW 1 clearly communicated her needs/ comfortable
level on this case, or the actual amount of support provided her is
not clear. Notwithstanding this, the evidence does not essentially
show the managerial staff did not demonstrate the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
Technical Assistance
The agency would be apprised to examine what happened related
to this case and to establish guidelines and or training around how
to better aid new and inexperienced workers in handling youths
with mental health concerns and severe boundary issues.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
